natural problem: How many elements are in the intersection of the set of all the prime numbers less than 30 and the set of all the odd numbers greater than zero?
natural solution: In other words, we're looking for the number of positive odd prime numbers less than 30.
We go through all odd numbers less than 30 and note how many of them are prime.
We get that 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, and 29 are all of the positive odd prime numbers less than 30, a total of $\boxed{9}$ elements in the intersection.

a_0.formal problem:
definition "prime_numbers_less_30 = {p. prime p \<and> p < (30::nat)}"
definition "odd_numbers_greater_0 = {n. odd n \<and> n > (0::nat)}"

theorem 
shows  "card (prime_numbers_less_30 \<inter> odd_numbers_greater_0) = 9"
end
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many elements are in the intersection of the set of all the prime numbers less than 30 and the set of all the odd numbers greater than zero? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 In other words, we're looking for the number of positive odd prime numbers less than 30.
 We go through all odd numbers less than 30 and note how many of them are prime.
 We get that 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, and 29 are all of the positive odd prime numbers less than 30, a total of $\boxed{9}$ elements in the intersection.
 *)



definition "prime_numbers_less_30 = {p. prime p \<and> p < (30::nat)}"
definition "odd_numbers_greater_0 = {n. odd n \<and> n > (0::nat)}"

theorem 
shows  "card (prime_numbers_less_30 \<inter> odd_numbers_greater_0) = 9"
end

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many prime numbers less than 30 are also odd numbers greater than 0? The final answer is 9.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {x. prime x \<and> x < 30}"
and h1 : "B = {x. odd x \<and> x > 0}"
shows  "card (A \<inter> B) = 9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many elements are in the intersection of the set of all the prime numbers less than 30 and the set of all the odd numbers greater than zero? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 In other words, we're looking for the number of positive odd prime numbers less than 30.
 We go through all odd numbers less than 30 and note how many of them are prime.
 We get that 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, and 29 are all of the positive odd prime numbers less than 30, a total of $\boxed{9}$ elements in the intersection.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {x. prime x \<and> x < 30}"
and h1 : "B = {x. odd x \<and> x > 0}"
shows  "card (A \<inter> B) = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Determine the number of elements in the set that includes prime numbers less than 30 and odd numbers greater than 0. The final answer is 9.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes PrimeNumbers OddNumbers :: "nat set"
defines "PrimeNumbers \<equiv> {x. prime x \<and> x < 30}"
and "OddNumbers \<equiv> {x. x mod 2 = 1 \<and> x > 0}"
shows  "card (PrimeNumbers \<inter> OddNumbers) = 9"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many elements are in the intersection of the set of all the prime numbers less than 30 and the set of all the odd numbers greater than zero? The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 In other words, we're looking for the number of positive odd prime numbers less than 30.
 We go through all odd numbers less than 30 and note how many of them are prime.
 We get that 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, and 29 are all of the positive odd prime numbers less than 30, a total of $\boxed{9}$ elements in the intersection.
 *)

theorem 
fixes PrimeNumbers OddNumbers :: "nat set"
defines "PrimeNumbers \<equiv> {x. prime x \<and> x < 30}"
and "OddNumbers \<equiv> {x. x mod 2 = 1 \<and> x > 0}"
shows  "card (PrimeNumbers \<inter> OddNumbers) = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: How many prime numbers less than 30 are also odd numbers? The final answer is 9.
